Quality of University Housing Debated
Bradford Residents Criticize Housing Office
by Laura Perkinson
Many Hopkins students, when
moving off campus after their
freshman year, chose to live in
university housing, both to stay
near campus, to live with other
students, and to enjoy the services
provided by the Johns Hopkins
Housing Office. But for 24 of the
150 students living in The Bradford, a university-owned apartment building which offers such
luxuries as air conditioning and
wall-to-wall carpeting, the comfort and convenience they had expected turned into a disaster soon
after they moved in.
On September 9, at approximately 3:00 a.m., water began
to leak through the ceiling of six
of the apartments, flooding
bedrooms, bathrooms, living
rooms, and hallways. The source

of the water leak was a pipe in
apartment 801 that had been
damaged.
The pipe had been punctured
by a screw when kitchen cabinets
were installed in the eighth floor
apartment by construction
workers earlier in this year. Continual pressure over several
weeks caused it to weaken until
finally it burst, causing water to
leak down to the apartments as far
below as the third floor.
The damage was extensive in
most of the apartments. Water
ruined the wall-to-wall carpeting
and the wooden floors beneath
and caused paint on the walls to
peel and chip. Some kitchen tiling and furniture had to be
repaired, and ceilings needed to
be replaced.
Hopkins students living in the
damaged Bradford apartments ex-

pressed their unhappiness with
the way the University handled
the incident. Evelyn Jerome, a
resident of apartment 701, expressed her frustration with the
housing office for failing to inform students when inspectors
would be coming to check the
damage and when repairs would
be made. Students complained
that there would often be groups
of ten or twelve people walking
in and out of their apartments, yet
they were never informed of who
they were or why they were
there. The Housing Office did not
respond to letters from students
asking for explanations.
Students also did not feel that
repairs were made -quickly
enough. The wet carpeting was
not removed until the following
Friday, and the walls and ceilings
were not replaced until two weeks
after the incident. Temporary
carpeting was laid down the next
Monday, but the new carpeting
will not be installed until
November 3.
Carol Mohr of the Housing Office stated that the University
made every effort to respond to
the situation as quickly as possible. "Our major concern was
speed," she said. While some
companies had estimated three to
four weeks to make the repairs,
the University insisted on having
the major work done in two
weeks. She explained that the
new carpeting had to be ordered
and therefore would not be

available until the end of October.
Temporary .carpeting was supplied as soon as possible,
however, she stated.
The reason for the lack ofcommunication with the students, according to Mohr, was the absence
of available information at the
time; the University had not
received any feedback from the
repairmen or the insurance company about when the repairs
would be completed.
Although students will still be
expected to pay the entire rent for
the month of September, the
Housing Office did offer to pay
September's electric bill for the
students, who were asked to run
dehumidifiers and to leave their
air conditioners on throughout the
week to air out the apartments.
To some students, however,
this is only a minimal compensation. Jerome proposed that the
students whose apartments were
damaged only pay three quarters
of the month's rent of $1260, but
the Housing Office has yet to respond to her suggestion. Mohr indicated, however, that there was
no plan on the part of the University to compensate the students
aside from paying the electric
bills for September.
She stated that "the University cannot predict such accidents
nor prevent them from happening.'

Addressing the issue of the
"War & Peace in the post-Cold
War world," Dr. Steven David
said, "I'm happy that the Cold

Garrett Room.

Science, at the University said

nostalgic for the days of the Cold
War, because it preserved peace
for the most part. He suggested
that the prospects for conflict and
instability in the world are now
greater.
Viewing the causes of war in
a three-level framework, David
identified elements in the present

which have led to war in the past.
His first level is that of the individual. David said, "People
have always been rotten, they are
rotten now, and they always will
be rotten." He said that individuals are just as likely to want
war today as the behavior of Saddam Hussein has demonstrated.
On the level of the state, he also
identified interests and objectives
that conflict then as now.
On the international system
level, David described a system
of international anarchy where
there is no arbitrator for disputes
between states. He said that the
United Nations provides "a
useful fig leaf for multilateral action" by its members. He suggested that the United Nations

Mark Crispin Miller heads "The Forum for the Study of Campaign

Campaign Propaganda
Studied in Forum
by Jack Lipkin
"The Forum for the Study of
Campaign Propaganda" made its
debut at Johns Hopkins on
Wednesday in the Arellano
Theater. Headed by Writing
Seminars Associate Professor
Mark Crispin Miller, the forum
was created "to improve people's
awareness of the way political ads
work visually."
In addition, the forum's goal is
to help viewers recognize the
visual tricks and devices used to
promote and sell the candidates.
Linda Benn of the University of
Maryland's American Studies
Department joined Miller in what
he referred to as the first of an
"experimental series of discussions."
Much of the hour-long forum
was devoted to the 1988
Presidential Campaign. Miller
explained that television campaign advertising for the
Democrats and Republicans did
not follow a rational format; it
was visual rather than verbal and
operated in a more visceral way.
He also said that these campaign
ads were much more influential
than ads for products. According
to Miller, advertising helped
decide the presidential race in
1988.
While the forum followed a
bipartisan approach in analyzing
television advertising, Miller and
Benn stressed the advantages
possessed by the Republican
Party. According to Benn,
"There is a unified vision of
wholeness in the Republicans'
ads." She added, "Their commercials work together to create
positive images for Bush and

negative ones for Dukakis." Four
such commercials were reviewed during the forum.
Benn explained, "Bush is
associated with the pillar of
strength. . . he's wearing red,
white, and blue. . .and exudes
purity and patriotism." She
noted, however,"No political or
factual substance is presented in
any of these commercials."
Miller added, "There is a constant association of Dukakis with
the excremental," as he referred
specifically to the Boston Harbor
commercial. "The Republicans
are characterized by the use of the
words 'we,' us,"family,' and
'hard work,' while the Democrats
are associated with 'failure,'
'taxes,'. . .'crime."
Miller said, however, "The
Republicans share a distinct advantage because the myth that
they sell is more suitable to television than the myth the Democrats
sell." He added, "The
Democrats are cursed with a
myth of diversity, the multiracial,
multiplicity, fragmentation, and
uneasiness. They don't as easily
focus on a unique characteristic
as the Republicans."
Miller and Benn also discussed the gubernatorial race in
California between former Congressman Pete Wilson and former
San Francisco Mayor Diana
Feinstein, as well as the North
Carolina senate race between
Jesse Helms and his black opponent Harvey Gantt.
"The most typical negative
ads," Miller said, "are the most

by News-Letter Staff
Last semester "a decision was
made by [former] President
[Steven] Muller in conjunction
with the Board of Trustees" to
rename Rowland Hall as Krieger
Hall, according to Dean of Arts
and Sciences Lloyd Armstrong.
Zanvyl Krieger has donated $7.5
million to fund the Krieger
Mind/Brain Institute which is
housed in that hall.
Dean Armstrong said that he is
"personally sorry to see the name
[Rowland] go," but that "time
marches on."
Professor Henry A. Rowland
was one of the foremost
physicists of the nineteenth century and among the original faculty at the University. His work
won international respect for both
Hopkins and himself.

ROTC Committee Serves No Purpose
"Hopkins is ten years behind its peer institutions in addressing this issue." Dean of Arts and Sciences Lloyd Armstrong
made this statement two and a half years ago in a meeting with
members of the Feminist Alliance (now the Women's Center).
He was refering to hiring policies and practices throughout the
University, in response to questions concerning the exceptionally low numbers of non-male, non-caucasian administrators and
tenured faculty members.
Now questions have been raised about another aspect of this
institution—ROTC. Dean Armstrong may have to pull his statement out of the stack of administrative "admissions" and use
it again soon, for there is no evidence that the questions of civil
(student) rights,jurisdiction, and complicity at the heart of the
ROTC "debate" will be intelligently or effectively addressed
by President Richardson and his fellow administrators.
Dean of Students Susan Boswell is the head of the committee appointed by Richardson to "examine the issue of ROTC
at Hopkins." In a prepared statement, however, Richardson
said that he "does not anticipate a circumstance under which
[the University] would sever its ties with the ROTC unit." Why,
then, has the committee been established, and what
can it accomplish?
Though the precise mission of the committee is not clear,
perhaps one of its charges is to determine if there is a conflict
between the values and mission of the University and the
Department of Defense, and if this conflict interferes substantially with the rights and well-being of members of the "Hopkins
community."
Department of Defense directive 1332.14 prohibits homosexuals from entering any branch of the armed forces. It is not
clear, however, what criteria the DoD uses to identify a
"homosexual" or how it upholds this directive. Recent evidence
in the media suggests that the most effective—and currently the
most "popular"—way to be excluded from the military for being a "homosexual"(or because of one's current or predominant sexual preference? or one's most recent physical intimacy

with another person?) is for someone already in the military
to stand up and say "I am gay." So the DoD prohibition is
enacted only after it has failed and a "homosexual" is serving
in the military.
With this in mind, and using reliable national data, it is highly
probable statistically that there are members of the Hopkins
ROTC program who identify themselves as "homosexuals."
There are administrators, faculty and staff members, and many
students (500? 750? 1000?) who fall into the category
"homosexual" as the DoD seems to use it. If so, there is nothing
to investigate—discrimination on the basis of "homosexuality" affects members of the Hopkins community.
Does the committee intend to investigate the positive versus
negative impact of having ROTC on our campus? There is no
way to measure the benefits enjoyed by a small number of
Hopkins students who participate in ROTC against the harm
caused by discrimination. The benefits of ROTC are not being
challenged. And many Hopkins students acquire financial aid
and leadership skills without the "help" of ROTC.
Across the country, colleges and universities are taking
definitive action to protest DoD policies and university complicity. Within the next two years, students at Harvard who
are members of an ROTC battalion at other campuses will no
longer be allowed to use ROTC funds for their Harvard education. (Harvard does not have its own ROTC program.) This
action, and actions like it, exert whatever influence possible
over the DoD while protecting the rights of the students.
Harvard ROTC cadets will have to look for either alternative
funds or an alternative school. But no student at Harvard will
wonder about her or his status because of her or his private
life. Hopkins students, faculty, staff, and administrators deserve
the same. They also deserve more than a perfunctory presidential committee with no charge other than to rubber-stamp
Richardson's unwillingness to take action on behalf of the
members of this University community.

In Which the Administration Learns 'Who Is Complaining',

To the Editors:

To the Editors:

I was deeply disturbed upon
reading last week's edition of the
News-Letter, in which various administrators directly or indirectly
defended their inexcusable lack of
action on the ROTC issue. I was not
amazed to find that President
Richardson justifies his lack of com-'
mittment to the issue by upholding
a conclusively ineffective letter sent
five months ago to Dick Cheney and
an ad hoc committee, which will
merely "prepare a report for
Richardson about ROTC at
Hopkins" but will not have any
undergraduate representation nor
any power over the final decision on
Hopkins policy. This stance is
nothing less than an attempt to put
off the issue in an extremely
bureaucratic way, in hope that the
most vocal of the "complainers"
will go away.
This raises the most important
question, presented last week as
"Who is complaining?" The
paragraphs that follow were simply
appalling. In them, Dean Armstrong, Bob Nelson, and Estelle
Fishbein stated that the issue has
seldom or never been brought to
their attention by students. In other
words, campus apathy is a sufficient
reason to ignore a vitally important
issue. Listen, if we waited for
students to raise a mob of protest for
every issue that concerned them,
most issues would never be addressed. It's a commonplace phenomenon
here at Hopkins—not enough people
take the time to show their support
for what they believe in, and virtually none put forth the effort to fight
the constant bureaucratic sedation in
order to make the essential changes.
I know that support exists for this
issue. Thankfully, someone has
finally emerged from the student
body who is willing to lead the fight
against the administration's
hypocracy. But we must all show
that we care enough to force a
change. We are being excluded from
the outcome of this debate because
the administration thinks we are one
man with a few enthusiastic letterwriters in his wake. We are indeed

To the Editors:
In recent weeks, the Johns
Hopkins community has been forced to confront the reality of
government-sponsered discrimination on its campus. The Department
of Defense's exclusionary policy
against gays and lesbians in ROTC
units is antithetical to the spirit and
letter of the University's stance
against discrimination. Yet, President Richardson, who in other
venues has expressed his belief in the
humanistic values of the institution,
says he "does not anticipate a circumstance under which the
University would sever its ties with
the ROTC unit." With his decision
on the issue apparently made,
Richardson is still going through the
charade of appointing a committee
on the ROTC issue, to be chaired by
Dean of Students Susan Boswell,
when Boswell has said herself, in the
September 28th News-Letter, that
"direction (on the ROTC issue) will
come from the President." The
President has set his direction it
seems, and it is time for those who
believe discrimination can play no
role on this campus to set our own.
Equally disturbing in last week's
article was the writer's rhetorical
question about who is raising all the
fuss about gays and lesbians in
ROTC in the first place. Dean Armstrong, Estelle Fishbein, University
General Counsel, and Bob Nelson,

Student Council President, are
quoted that they have heard little or
no direct protest on the issue. The
clear implication is that if no one is
complaining, nothing is wrong, and
nothing needs to be done. This "let's
not rock the boat" if we're not sinking philosophy may be fine when it
comes to issues like a student union,
course offerings and the like, but it
is morally incompatible with clearcut issues of discrimination.
Moreover, has anyone realized that
gay and lesbian students in ROTC
may not be complaining for fear of
losing scholarships in the program?
Admittedly, Paul DelGrosso, President of GALA,has raised this issue,
but by no means should this be seen
as GALA's struggle alone. Nor is
this effort anti-ROTC or antimilitary,, but rather a case against a
discriminatory policy that conflicts
with the mandate of the university,
Ultimately, what saddens me the
most is that we need a Paul
DelGrosso to remind our community of its legal and moral obligations
to its members.
Jonathan Roberts

Kenny Rogers—Love Is Strange
(Reprise)
First, I should recommend a
change of title to Love Is Strange
And Variations, for the ten songs
on Kenny Rogers' most recent
album are virtually indistinguishable from one another.
I know that many people think all
country music sounds the same;
it doesn't, but these songs most
emphatically do. With Love Is
Strange, Rogers has glided onto
a new, impressively barren plane.
This is a musical universe that
allows for no variation, a place
where emotion collapses into an
antiseptic infinity of lyrics with
as much personality as an average
clump of astroturf.
But is this country music? It
might not be fair to pigeonhole
the man who gave the world
"The Gambler," "Lady," and
my favorite, "Coward of • the
County." Love Is Strange contains none of the things that I
associate with good country
music—small-town tales, occasionally cheesy but heartfelt instrumental work, lyrics that explore bizarre but functional
relationships—except its traditional brand of cutesy sexism,

which is in abundant evidence.
Not all of the songs are predictable, but those that aren't (like
the nauseous "If! Were A Painting")are so third-grade insightful
that, after fifteen seconds, you'll
be aching to hear an instrumental —which you won't.
It's not just that Love Is Strange
is stupid: there isn't any music
here. You can hear occasional
traces of melody—it hums on the
edge of the mix, like the sound
trapped inside a sea shell—but as
Gertrude Stein once said in
another context, "There isn't any
there there." Rogers has a voice
which is two parts fuzzy warmth
and no part human: he seems convinced that singing each line as
if he has just exhausted his oxygen supply will make an emotional statement. It doesn't.
To make the point, however,
recall the commercials Rogers did
recently for Dole, which are
perhaps his most memorable
work in years. Think of the lyrics
("The perfect vacation from
orange juice is Dole") and the
tune—memorable, right? Love Is
Strange offers nothing half so
tuneful, and I got far more intellectual mileage wondering how
to take a vacation from a
breakfast drink than I did from
anything on this poor, poor recording. Avoid.
—Hart Ford

gregarious owner, is the atmosphere. It is the kind of cafe
that makes you want to linger, not
for the dread of what the library
or laboratory holds, but for the
place's own inherent qualities : a
certain calm, a pleasant airiness,
an elusive flair you may have experienced in a Parisian or
Milanese sidewalk cafe but that
you never dared dream of so

close to campus.
The menu at the Unlimited

is based on salads, sweets, and

dishes, the way the owner says

delicacies as chicken stoly (probably the most popular item),
vareniki, spinach lasagna, and

chick peas and spinach.

all homemade, and Irina will probably start opening for a "European style" breakfast (alas, no
bacon and eggs) in the near
future. She is considering converting the second floor into a bed
and breakfast establishment.
A Soviet emigrant and the
youngest of three children, Irina
owns her business and the
rowhouse that houses it. Her
mother, sister, nephew, and other
family and friends help cook and
run the business. Irina started
catering out of her home five
years ago, at the age of twentyfive, as a hobby on the weekends.
She eventually quit her job as
a computer programmer/consultant and moved her business to

Charles Village because she
needed a commercial kitchen for
catering. She began serving

talk. To meet the demands of the

singular salt and pepper shakers

From The Features Recipe File:

Paragon Soup
by Hart Ford
Not a soup for the dainty. It has
dainty potential, of course; possible variations on the recipe are
endless. A a rule, though, this is
relatively grubby soup (or
stew—see below) that is
nourishing, filling, and inexpensive to make.
It should come as no surprise,
then, that the title is something of
a joke. It comes from Scott
Joplin's "Paragon Rag"(1909),
which played incessantly when
the first batch was improvised.
Since improvisation has proven
essential to every batch

thereafter, it seemed only right to
credit one of the fathers of jazz
with its inception. Make no
mistake: this soup is a paragon of
nothing, except perhaps simplicity or economy.
The perfect time to make
Paragon Soup is when the produce drawer of your refrigerator
is brimming with salvageable
vegetables in inconvienient portions. Beyond those suggested
below, broccoli, cauliflower, and
green pepper are all healthy additions to the overall flavor of the
soup, as is a restrained dose of
pasta.

motley of ailments which go hand
in hand with had raw seafood.

should.

Crucial Conference Competition
by Mary Hillebrand
The Men's Soccer Team may
not have outscored Dickinson
College last Saturday, but they
did come out ahead in a different
category—official warning
cards—marking eight to Dickinson's zero on the evening.
Although the scoring was
balanced among the two teams,
each netting one goal and
finishing the game in a tie,
Hopkins players could not say the
same thing for the officiating. In
what they had hoped would be a
typical eleven vs. eleven soccer
match, the visiting Blue Jays
found instead a "lopsided" game
that included both officials and
Dickinson players on the home
team roster.
"The cards wouldn't have been
that unusual if the refs had called the game evenly. But when
your team gets seven yellows and
they get none, you have to
wonder," said senior co-captain
Geoff Manning.
Warren Jones, the other
Hopkins co-captain and recipient
of the game's only red card,
agreed. "The refereeing was
ridiculous. They weren't carding
at all for physical fouls, but they
did for moronic reasons [like talking to officials]."
Indeed, the referees accepted
no lobbying from the Blue Jays,
first slapping Jones with a yellow
warning card in a dispute over the
ten-yard free kick zone, then with
a red card for applauding a call
later in the game. "I guess the ref
thought I was being sarcastic or
something, but even then I
shouldn't have been carded for
it," Jones explained.
Jones and Manning were quick
to admit, though, that the officiating was not the only factor
barring a Hopkins win. The Blue
Jays set the tempo and stayed
with their game plan, but
squandered numerous scoring opportunities, Manning said. Early in the first game, senior mid-

fielder Rich Bronshvag capitalized on classmate Andrew Janis'
pass to net Hopkins' only goal.
"We have had the same problem throughout the season,"
Jones explained."We go out and
score early and then relax, thinking we've got the game won."
The Blue Jays paid dearly for
the lapse, struggling through two
overtimes before finally ending
the game in a draw. "That kind
of game gets you fired up, but it's
also frustrating. It makes you
want to go right back out there
and play again," Jones said.
Despite the frustration, the
Blue Jays were able to call on
their positive attitude to carry
them into the next game, said
head coach Mark Butler. "The
team is able to recognize that on
any given day something could
happen that is beyond their power
to control.. .it could just be their
opponent's lucky day, so this
doesn't affect them very much."
If anything, the players channeled their frustration toward a
sound defeat of Western
Maryland on Tuesday afternoon
in Lancaster. Though the chief
difference between the two games
was "clearly the officiating,"
Manning said, the Blue Jays also
showed exceptional control in adjusting their game plan to fit the
host team's physical style.
"We were very casual and
worked the ball well. Because of
their short field, we were able to
sit back in a defensive posture and
control the game from our own
half of the field," Manning explained, crediting Butler with a
shrewd change in strategy.
Bronshvag again led the Blue
Jay attack, scoring the team's first
goal 22 minutes into the game on
a pass from junior midfielder
Myles Flynn. The Green Terror
struck back ten minutes later to
tie the score, but this time
• Hopkins did not relax.
Sophomore defenseman Mike
Vandekieft set up senior forward
Todd Marshall just two minutes
later, to give Hopkins a 2-1 edge

at half-time.
In the second half, Vandekieft
again took charge, making a
brilliant run down the sideline and
drawing a foul inside the penalty
box. Bronshvag scored on the ensuing penalty kick to seal the 3-1
victory.
Butler complimented the play
of his reserves, who were called
upon to fill in gaps left by Janis
and Jones, respectively sidelined
with an injury and a red card
from the previous game. "They
were up for the challenge, but I
expected it of them," Butler commented. "I am never concerned
about putting any one player in
because I know they'll adjust and
do what we need them to do.
"Recently Nick Martin has
been our most stable player," he
continued. "We can always count
on him to do his job. But really,
the whole team collectively stands
out."
Scoring has been remarkably
spread out this season, with ten
different Blue Jays logging goals
or assists in the ten games played
to date. "That says a lot for them.
They are not selfish, (they are]
always working for the advancement of the team. Instead of being greedy, they'll give up a shot
to someone else who might have
a better angle," Butler said.
The composure and teamwork
that the Blue Jays have shown
thus far will be put to the test
Saturday night in a crucial home
match against Swarthmore. "It's
a seriously big game," Manning
said of this season's edition of the
two teams' thirty-four year old
rivalry. "We will definitely be
pumped for it."
"It will be a really tough game,
without question, and the success
of the rest of the season hinges on
it," Butler agreed, emphasizing
the importance of a spirited
crowd.
"Our guys are going to play as
hard as they can possibly play,
but there is no home field advantage without the support of the
school."

Overmatches Jays Fall Squad

The Hopkins Baseball Team
got a one-time-only taste of the
big leagues last Friday night
when it squared off against the
Baltimore Orioles Instructional
League Team at Frederick
Stadium, home of the Orioles
Single A team, the Frederick
Keys.
The Orioles Instructional Team,
comprised of low level minor
league players (mostly first year
professionals and single A
players), is far from the O's major league club but highlights
some bonafide major league prospects. Shortstop Manny Alexander, who plays for the
Frederick Keys is the most
notable while thirdbaseman Pete
Rose Jr., the son of now incarcerated baseball great Pete
Rose, is no doubt the most
famous.
Looking at the score alone, the
Blue Jays suffered a thorough 9-1
trouncing. However, the Blue
Jays managed to stay close
through six innings, mostly
behind the pitching of sophomore
Joe Tortorello.
Tortorello allowed just two
runs in his six innings of work.
"He mixed speed well, kept them
off balance," coach Andy Karetsky said of his pitcher's performance. "He had them out on
their front foot all night."
Numerous overanxious Oriole
batters popped up due to his baffling change of pace.
Tortorello, only scheduled to
pitch six innings, was relieved in
the top of the seventh inning trailing 2-1 by senior Dave Kiskis.
Kiskis was peppered for six runs
in two-thirds of an inning of
work. His tendency to keep the
ball up in the strike zone caused
much of the problem. He was

subsequently relieved by junior
Mike Metz who pitched one and
one third innings before giving
way to senior Ken Brodkowitz in
the ninth.
On the other side of home
plate, Hopkins' batters struggled
with a higher caliber of pitcher
than they are used to. The Orioles
pitching staff, feeding the Blue
Jays a steady diet of 80 mile per
hour fastballs and hard sliders,
allowed just four hits. One hit
though, was a bomb, accounting
for the Blue Jays' only run. In the
top of the third inning junior second baseman Mike Frazier
blasted a solo homerun deep over
the left field wall to give Hopkins
its only lead, 1-0.
"Our hitters were completely
outmatched," said Karetsky.
"We don't see that quality of pitching ever."
Hopkins' pitcher Rob Walter
echoed those sentiments. "Their
pitching outmatched us. We
haven't seen anyone that speed
and our players aren't hitting the
ball like they will be in the
spring," he said.
"We didn't know what to expect coming in," Karetsky added, "but!think we made a good
showing. This is the only outside
competition we face so it was a
good chance to see our whole first
unit play together." When asked for an evaluation of the team
at this point Karetsky stated simpinexperly,
"We're
ienced but good."
It seems that some of those
freshmen accounting for the inexperience are moving to the
foreground in the battle for the
varsity spots in the spring.
Smooth fielding shortstop Joe
Kail, second baseman Mike
Arenth and pitcher Ryan Rippen
received mention for their steady
play this fall.

Bradford Residents Criticize Housing Office
by Laura Perkinson
Many Hopkins students, when
moving off campus after their
freshman year, chose to live in
university housing, both to stay
near campus, to live with other
students, and to enjoy the services
provided by the Johns Hopkins
Housing Office. But for 24 of the
150 students living in The Bradford, a university-owned apartment building which offers such
luxuries as air conditioning and
wall-to-wall carpeting, the comfort and convenience they had expected turned into a disaster soon
after they moved in.
On September 9, at approximately 3:00 a.m., water began
to leak through the ceiling of six
of the apartments, flooding
bedrooms, bathrooms, living
rooms, and hallways. The source

of the water leak was a pipe in
apartment 801 that had been
damaged.
The pipe had been punctured
by a screw when kitchen cabinets
were installed in the eighth floor
apartment by construction
workers earlier in this year. Continual pressure over several
weeks caused it to weaken until
finally it burst, causing water to
leak down to the apartments as far
below as the third floor.
The damage was extensive in
most of the apartments. Water
ruined the wall-to-wall carpeting
and the wooden floors beneath
and caused paint on the walls to
peel and chip. Some kitchen tiling and furniture had to be
repaired, and ceilings needed to
be replaced.

Studied in Forum

"The Forum for the Study of
Campaign Propaganda" made its
debut at Johns Hopkins on
Wednesday in the Arellano
Theater. Headed by Writing
Seminars Associate Professor
Mark Crispin Miller, the forum
was created "to improve people's
awareness of the way political ads
work visually."
In addition, the forum's goal is
to help viewers recognize the
visual tricks and devices used to
promote and sell the candidates.
Linda Benn of the University of
Maryland's American Studies
Department joined Miller in what
he referred to as the first of an
"experimental series of discussions."
Much of the hour-long forum
was devoted to the 1988
Presidential Campaign. Miller
explained that television campaign advertising for the
Democrats and Republicans did
not follow a rational format; it
was visual rather than verbal and
operated in a more visceral way.
He also said that these campaign
ads were much more influential
than ads for products. According
to Miller, advertising helped
decide the presidential race in
1988.
While the forum followed a
bipartisan approach in analyzing
television advertising, Miller and
Benn stressed the advantages
possessed by the Republican
Party. According to Benn,
"There is a unified vision of
wholeness in the Republicans'
ads." She added, "Their commercials work together to create
positive images for Bush and

negative ones for Dukakis." Four
such commercials were reviewed during the forum.
Benn explained, "Bush is
associated with the pillar of
strength. . . he's wearing red,
white, and blue. . .and exudes
purity and patriotism." She
noted, however,"No political or
factual substance is presented in
any of these commercials."

specifically to the Boston Harbor

are characterized by the use of the
words 'we,' us,"family,' and
'hard work,' while the Democrats

'taxes,'. . .'crime."

Republicans share a distinct advantage because the myth that

sell." He added, "The

focus on a unique characteristic

members of the Feminist Alliance (now the Women's Center).
He was refering to hiring policies and practices throughout the
University, in response to questions concerning the exceptionally low numbers of non-male, non-caucasian administrators and
tenured faculty members.
Now questions have been raised about another aspect of this
institution—ROTC. Dean Armstrong may have to pull his statement out of the stack of administrative "admissions" and use
it again soon, for there is no evidence that the questions of civil
(student) rights,jurisdiction, and complicity at the heart of the
ROTC "debate" will be intelligently or effectively addressed
by President Richardson and his fellow administrators.
Dean of Students Susan Boswell is the head of the committee appointed by Richardson to "examine the issue of ROTC
at Hopkins." In a prepared statement, however, Richardson
said that he "does not anticipate a circumstance under which
[the University] would sever its ties with the ROTC unit." Why,
then, has the committee been established, and what
can it accomplish?
Though the precise mission of the committee is not clear,
perhaps one of its charges is to determine if there is a conflict
between the values and mission of the University and the
Department of Defense, and if this conflict interferes substantially with the rights and well-being of members of the "Hopkins
community."
Department of Defense directive 1332.14 prohibits homosexuals from entering any branch of the armed forces. It is not
clear, however, what criteria the DoD uses to identify a
"homosexual" or how it upholds this directive. Recent evidence
in the media suggests that the most effective—and currently the
most "popular"—way to be excluded from the military for being a "homosexual"(or because of one's current or predominant sexual preference? or one's most recent physical intimacy

with another person?) is for someone already in the military
to stand up and say "I am gay." So the DoD prohibition is
enacted only after it has failed and a "homosexual" is serving
in the military.
With this in mind, and using reliable national data, it is highly
probable statistically that there are members of the Hopkins
ROTC program who identify themselves as "homosexuals."
There are administrators, faculty and staff members, and many
students (500? 750? 1000?) who fall into the category
"homosexual" as the DoD seems to use it. If so, there is nothing
to investigate—discrimination on the basis of "homosexuality" affects members of the Hopkins community.
Does the committee intend to investigate the positive versus
negative impact of having ROTC on our campus? There is no
way to measure the benefits enjoyed by a small number of
Hopkins students who participate in ROTC against the harm
caused by discrimination. The benefits of ROTC are not being
challenged. And many Hopkins students acquire financial aid
and leadership skills without the "help" of ROTC.
Across the country, colleges and universities are taking
definitive action to protest DoD policies and university complicity. Within the next two years, students at Harvard who
are members of an ROTC battalion at other campuses will no
longer be allowed to use ROTC funds for their Harvard education. (Harvard does not have its own ROTC program.) This
action, and actions like it, exert whatever influence possible
over the DoD while protecting the rights of the students.
Harvard ROTC cadets will have to look for either alternative
funds or an alternative school. But no student at Harvard will
wonder about her or his status because of her or his private
life. Hopkins students, faculty, staff, and administrators deserve
the same. They also deserve more than a perfunctory presidential committee with no charge other than to rubber-stamp
Richardson's unwillingness to take action on behalf of the
members of this University community.

To the Editors:

I was deeply disturbed upon

off the issue in an extremely
bureaucratic way, in hope that the

body who is willing to lead the fight

hypocracy. But we must all show

To the Editors:
In recent weeks, the Johns
Hopkins community has been forced to confront the reality of
government-sponsered discrimination on its campus. The Department
of Defense's exclusionary policy
against gays and lesbians in ROTC
units is antithetical to the spirit and
letter of the University's stance
against discrimination. Yet, President Richardson, who in other
venues has expressed his belief in the
humanistic values of the institution,
says he "does not anticipate a circumstance under which the
University would sever its ties with
the ROTC unit." With his decision
on the issue apparently made,
Richardson is still going through the
charade of appointing a committee
on the ROTC issue, to be chaired by
Dean of Students Susan Boswell,
when Boswell has said herself, in the
September 28th News-Letter, that
"direction (on the ROTC issue) will
come from the President." The
President has set his direction it
seems, and it is time for those who
believe discrimination can play no
role on this campus to set our own.
Equally disturbing in last week's
article was the writer's rhetorical
question about who is raising all the
fuss about gays and lesbians in
ROTC in the first place. Dean Armstrong, Estelle Fishbein, University
General Counsel, and Bob Nelson,

Student Council President, are
quoted that they have heard little or
no direct protest on the issue. The
clear implication is that if no one is
complaining, nothing is wrong, and
nothing needs to be done. This "let's
not rock the boat" if we're not sinking philosophy may be fine when it
comes to issues like a student union,
course offerings and the like, but it
is morally incompatible with clearcut issues of discrimination.
Moreover, has anyone realized that
gay and lesbian students in ROTC
may not be complaining for fear of
losing scholarships in the program?
Admittedly, Paul DelGrosso, President of GALA,has raised this issue,
but by no means should this be seen
as GALA's struggle alone. Nor is
this effort anti-ROTC or antimilitary,, but rather a case against a
discriminatory policy that conflicts
with the mandate of the university,
Ultimately, what saddens me the
most is that we need a Paul
DelGrosso to remind our community of its legal and moral obligations
to its members.
Jonathan Roberts

His seventy-six-year-old voice

lonely old man, living out his last

days and hating the world. "What
are you here for?" he bellows to
open the album. "We're all here
to go, that's what we're here
for." Burroughs stumbles
through the material, spitting out
telling asides and satirizing
everything from Thanksgiving
dinner to the Bible.
Producer Willner went to Burroughs' house in Lawrence, Kansas, and recorded Burroughs
reading excerpts from his books
and other writings as well as
various conversations and stories.
Burroughs reads from The
Naked Lunch, The Western
Lands, Tornado Alley, and

Prayer" and "Ah Pook The

brilliant voice. Also included are

sounds), John Cale, and Donald
Fagen, whose old band, Steely
Dan, took its name from The

Kenny Rogers—Love Is Strange
(Reprise)
First, I should recommend a
change of title to Love Is Strange
And Variations, for the ten songs
on Kenny Rogers' most recent
album are virtually indistinguishable from one another.
I know that many people think all
country music sounds the same;
it doesn't, but these songs most
emphatically do. With Love Is
Strange, Rogers has glided onto
a new, impressively barren plane.
This is a musical universe that
allows for no variation, a place
where emotion collapses into an
antiseptic infinity of lyrics with
as much personality as an average
clump of astroturf.
But is this country music? It
might not be fair to pigeonhole
the man who gave the world
"The Gambler," "Lady," and
my favorite, "Coward of • the
County." Love Is Strange contains none of the things that I
associate with good country
music—small-town tales, occasionally cheesy but heartfelt instrumental work, lyrics that explore bizarre but functional
relationships—except its traditional brand of cutesy sexism,

which is in abundant evidence.
Not all of the songs are predictable, but those that aren't (like
the nauseous "If! Were A Painting")are so third-grade insightful
that, after fifteen seconds, you'll
be aching to hear an instrumental —which you won't.
It's not just that Love Is Strange
is stupid: there isn't any music
here. You can hear occasional
traces of melody—it hums on the
edge of the mix, like the sound
trapped inside a sea shell—but as
Gertrude Stein once said in
another context, "There isn't any
there there." Rogers has a voice
which is two parts fuzzy warmth
and no part human: he seems convinced that singing each line as
if he has just exhausted his oxygen supply will make an emotional statement. It doesn't.
To make the point, however,
recall the commercials Rogers did
recently for Dole, which are
perhaps his most memorable
work in years. Think of the lyrics
("The perfect vacation from
orange juice is Dole") and the
tune—memorable, right? Love Is
Strange offers nothing half so
tuneful, and I got far more intellectual mileage wondering how
to take a vacation from a
breakfast drink than I did from
anything on this poor, poor recording. Avoid.
—Hart Ford

The Gilman Coffee Shop is irreplaceable, but for that real
"Euro Cafe" feeling (and coffee), where can you go? There is
a jewel of a cafe in our midst, but,
according to Irina Barshay,
owner of Unlimited Range
Gourmet Foods & Catering, a
few graduate students and professors are the only ones on the
Homewood Campus who know
about it.
The next time you want to take
a friend to a real cafe, walk up
to Barclay and 32 Streets. The
coffee is freshly ground French
and Italian roast, "by far the best
to be found in Charles Villiage."
For those of you who don't use
caffeine, Irina offers decaf and
"compote," a homemade fruit
drink.
But what is most wonderful
about Irina's, as you will come
to see once you have met the
gregarious owner, is the atmosphere. It is the kind of cafe
that makes you want to linger, not
for the dread of what the library
or laboratory holds, but for the
place's own inherent qualities : a
certain calm, a pleasant airiness,
an elusive flair you may have experienced in a Parisian or
Milanese sidewalk cafe but that
you never dared dream of so

close to campus.
The menu at the Unlimited
Range (Irina tells me they're probably going to change the name)
is based on salads, sweets, and
Ukrainian and house specialties.
You can eat lunch or dinner for $7
to $12, sampling many different
dishes, the way the owner says
she likes to eat. They offer such
delicacies as chicken stoly (probably the most popular item),
vareniki, spinach lasagna, and
stuffed zucchini; the salads range
from olivie, curried cauliflower,
and sweet pepper and carrots to
chick peas and spinach.
The tarts, pies, and muffins are
all homemade, and Irina will probably start opening for a "European style" breakfast (alas, no
bacon and eggs) in the near
future. She is considering converting the second floor into a bed
and breakfast establishment.
A Soviet emigrant and the
youngest of three children, Irina
owns her business and the
rowhouse that houses it. Her
mother, sister, nephew, and other
family and friends help cook and
run the business. Irina started
catering out of her home five
years ago, at the age of twentyfive, as a hobby on the weekends.
She eventually quit her job as
a computer programmer/consultant and moved her business to

Charles Village because she
needed a commercial kitchen for
catering. She began serving
customers on a strictly carry-out
basis until she saw how interested
people were in a place to sit and
talk. To meet the demands of the
neighborhood, her spacious dining room filled up, from one table
to the five it holds now.
You should go to Irina's if for
no other reason than to see her
locally handcrafted tables, each
one different from the next, and
to savour her cozy dining
clusters. The tables, chairs, and
singular salt and pepper shakers
simply radiate pizazz.

Paragon Soup
by Hart Ford
Not a soup for the dainty. It has
dainty potential, of course; possible variations on the recipe are
endless. A a rule, though, this is
relatively grubby soup (or
stew—see below) that is
nourishing, filling, and inexpensive to make.
It should come as no surprise,
then, that the title is something of
a joke. It comes from Scott
Joplin's "Paragon Rag"(1909),
which played incessantly when
the first batch was improvised.
Since improvisation has proven
essential to every batch

thereafter, it seemed only right to
credit one of the fathers of jazz
with its inception. Make no
mistake: this soup is a paragon of
nothing, except perhaps simplicity or economy.
The perfect time to make
Paragon Soup is when the produce drawer of your refrigerator
is brimming with salvageable
vegetables in inconvienient portions. Beyond those suggested
below, broccoli, cauliflower, and
green pepper are all healthy additions to the overall flavor of the
soup, as is a restrained dose of
pasta.

Crucial Conference Competition
by Mary Hillebrand
The Men's Soccer Team may
not have outscored Dickinson
College last Saturday, but they
did come out ahead in a different
category—official warning
cards—marking eight to Dickinson's zero on the evening.
Although the scoring was
balanced among the two teams,
each netting one goal and
finishing the game in a tie,
Hopkins players could not say the
same thing for the officiating. In
what they had hoped would be a
typical eleven vs. eleven soccer
match, the visiting Blue Jays
found instead a "lopsided" game
that included both officials and
Dickinson players on the home
team roster.
"The cards wouldn't have been
that unusual if the refs had called the game evenly. But when
your team gets seven yellows and
they get none, you have to
wonder," said senior co-captain
Geoff Manning.
Warren Jones, the other
Hopkins co-captain and recipient
of the game's only red card,
agreed. "The refereeing was
ridiculous. They weren't carding
at all for physical fouls, but they
did for moronic reasons [like talking to officials]."
Indeed, the referees accepted
no lobbying from the Blue Jays,
first slapping Jones with a yellow
warning card in a dispute over the
ten-yard free kick zone, then with
a red card for applauding a call
later in the game. "I guess the ref
thought I was being sarcastic or
something, but even then I
shouldn't have been carded for
it," Jones explained.
Jones and Manning were quick
to admit, though, that the officiating was not the only factor
barring a Hopkins win. The Blue
Jays set the tempo and stayed
with their game plan, but
squandered numerous scoring opportunities, Manning said. Early in the first game, senior mid-

fielder Rich Bronshvag capitalized on classmate Andrew Janis'
pass to net Hopkins' only goal.
"We have had the same problem throughout the season,"
Jones explained."We go out and
score early and then relax, thinking we've got the game won."
The Blue Jays paid dearly for
the lapse, struggling through two
overtimes before finally ending
the game in a draw. "That kind
of game gets you fired up, but it's
also frustrating. It makes you
want to go right back out there
and play again," Jones said.
Despite the frustration, the
Blue Jays were able to call on
their positive attitude to carry
them into the next game, said
head coach Mark Butler. "The
team is able to recognize that on
any given day something could
happen that is beyond their power
to control.. .it could just be their
opponent's lucky day, so this
doesn't affect them very much."
If anything, the players channeled their frustration toward a
sound defeat of Western
Maryland on Tuesday afternoon
in Lancaster. Though the chief
difference between the two games
was "clearly the officiating,"
Manning said, the Blue Jays also
showed exceptional control in adjusting their game plan to fit the
host team's physical style.
"We were very casual and
worked the ball well. Because of
their short field, we were able to
sit back in a defensive posture and
control the game from our own
half of the field," Manning explained, crediting Butler with a
shrewd change in strategy.
Bronshvag again led the Blue
Jay attack, scoring the team's first
goal 22 minutes into the game on
a pass from junior midfielder
Myles Flynn. The Green Terror
struck back ten minutes later to
tie the score, but this time
• Hopkins did not relax.
Sophomore defenseman Mike
Vandekieft set up senior forward
Todd Marshall just two minutes
later, to give Hopkins a 2-1 edge

at half-time.
In the second half, Vandekieft
again took charge, making a
brilliant run down the sideline and
drawing a foul inside the penalty
box. Bronshvag scored on the ensuing penalty kick to seal the 3-1
victory.
Butler complimented the play
of his reserves, who were called
upon to fill in gaps left by Janis
and Jones, respectively sidelined
with an injury and a red card
from the previous game. "They
were up for the challenge, but I
expected it of them," Butler commented. "I am never concerned
about putting any one player in
because I know they'll adjust and
do what we need them to do.
"Recently Nick Martin has
been our most stable player," he
continued. "We can always count
on him to do his job. But really,
the whole team collectively stands
out."
Scoring has been remarkably
spread out this season, with ten
different Blue Jays logging goals
or assists in the ten games played
to date. "That says a lot for them.
They are not selfish, (they are]
always working for the advancement of the team. Instead of being greedy, they'll give up a shot
to someone else who might have
a better angle," Butler said.
The composure and teamwork
that the Blue Jays have shown
thus far will be put to the test
Saturday night in a crucial home
match against Swarthmore. "It's
a seriously big game," Manning
said of this season's edition of the
two teams' thirty-four year old
rivalry. "We will definitely be
pumped for it."
"It will be a really tough game,
without question, and the success
of the rest of the season hinges on
it," Butler agreed, emphasizing
the importance of a spirited
crowd.
"Our guys are going to play as
hard as they can possibly play,
but there is no home field advantage without the support of the
school."

by Ben Runkle
The Men's and Women's
Cross Country Teams, challenged by the heat and a fast course,
turned in impressive performances at the Dickinson Invitational on Saturday, finishing in
third place in their respective
divisions.
Out of a field of twelve teams,
the men's team captured their
place with 89 points, just behind
Moravian (69 points) and Scranton (79 points). Allentown finished a distant fourth with 130
points.
Leading the way for the Blue
Jays was co-captain John Robinson, who finished in second place
with a time of 26:30, 13 seconds
behind winner Rob Patten of
Moravian. Also running strong
races for the Blue Jays were Manny Hostin (28:39, 17th place), cocaptain Basil Dahiyat (28:52,
19th place), Mark Melia (28:56,
20th) and Gabe Kaufman (29:20,
30th).
"We ran a very strong race,"
said men's coach Jim Grogan.
"Everyone ran up to their potential." The fast times were
especially impressive for the hot
weather, Grogan added. This
race could be a good predictor of
the team's performance in the
MACs at the end of the year. The
Blue Jays were without their
number two runner, Pete Gliatto, who very well may have been
the difference between winning
the race and finishing third. Also,
Moravian is a strong team, having finished second in the MACs
last season.
The women's team finished in
third place out of thirteen teams
with 100 points, trailing the easy
winner Dickinson (25 points) and
Haverford (100 points). Tami
Myers paced the Hopkins women
with an impressive fifth place
finish, covering the three mile
cotirse, in 20:17., Also rtihnng
another strong rade for the Blue
Jays was Tatiana Aguirre, who
finished in eighth place with a
time of 20:29. Carol Moylan
(20:58, 17th place), Andrea
Wenger(21:55, 34th), and Hope
Raschke (23:05, 36th) also ran
strong races.

Orioles Rookie League Team
Overmatches Jays Fall Squad
by Danny Knee
The Hopkins Baseball Team
got a one-time-only taste of the
big leagues last Friday night
when it squared off against the
Baltimore Orioles Instructional
League Team at Frederick
Stadium, home of the Orioles
Single A team, the Frederick
Keys.
The Orioles Instructional Team,
comprised of low level minor
league players (mostly first year
professionals and single A
players), is far from the O's major league club but highlights
some bonafide major league prospects. Shortstop Manny Alexander, who plays for the
Frederick Keys is the most
notable while thirdbaseman Pete
Rose Jr., the son of now incarcerated baseball great Pete
Rose, is no doubt the most
famous.
Looking at the score alone, the
Blue Jays suffered a thorough 9-1
trouncing. However, the Blue
Jays managed to stay close
through six innings, mostly
behind the pitching of sophomore
Joe Tortorello.
Tortorello allowed just two
runs in his six innings of work.
"He mixed speed well, kept them
off balance," coach Andy Karetsky said of his pitcher's performance. "He had them out on
their front foot all night."
Numerous overanxious Oriole
batters popped up due to his baffling change of pace.
Tortorello, only scheduled to
pitch six innings, was relieved in
the top of the seventh inning trailing 2-1 by senior Dave Kiskis.
Kiskis was peppered for six runs
in two-thirds of an inning of
work. His tendency to keep the
ball up in the strike zone caused
much of the problem. He was

subsequently relieved by junior
Mike Metz who pitched one and
one third innings before giving
way to senior Ken Brodkowitz in
the ninth.
On the other side of home
plate, Hopkins' batters struggled
with a higher caliber of pitcher
than they are used to. The Orioles
pitching staff, feeding the Blue
Jays a steady diet of 80 mile per
hour fastballs and hard sliders,
allowed just four hits. One hit
though, was a bomb, accounting
for the Blue Jays' only run. In the
top of the third inning junior second baseman Mike Frazier
blasted a solo homerun deep over
the left field wall to give Hopkins
its only lead, 1-0.
"Our hitters were completely
outmatched," said Karetsky.
"We don't see that quality of pitching ever."
Hopkins' pitcher Rob Walter
echoed those sentiments. "Their
pitching outmatched us. We
haven't seen anyone that speed
and our players aren't hitting the
ball like they will be in the
spring," he said.
"We didn't know what to expect coming in," Karetsky added, "but!think we made a good
showing. This is the only outside
competition we face so it was a
good chance to see our whole first
unit play together." When asked for an evaluation of the team
at this point Karetsky stated simpinexperly,
"We're
ienced but good."
It seems that some of those
freshmen accounting for the inexperience are moving to the
foreground in the battle for the
varsity spots in the spring.
Smooth fielding shortstop Joe
Kail, second baseman Mike
Arenth and pitcher Ryan Rippen
received mention for their steady
play this fall.
